Using executive orders to bypass the traditional legislative process in Congress can have implications for the functioning of American democracy, particularly in terms of polarization and partisanship in government. When a president uses executive orders to push through policy changes or initiatives without the input or approval of Congress, it can create tensions between the executive and legislative branches. Members of Congress may feel that their role in the democratic process is being undermined, and may be less willing to cooperate or compromise on policy in the future. This can contribute to a more adversarial political climate and make it harder for the government to function effectively.

Additionally, executive orders issued by a president of one political party can generate resistance and criticism from members of the opposing party, contributing to increased polarization and partisanship. This can further exacerbate gridlock and hinder progress on important policy issues.

That being said, the use of executive orders can also be a necessary tool for a president to take action quickly in response to emergencies or other urgent situations, especially if Congress is not able to act effectively. The implications of a president's use of executive orders depend on the specific context and the nature of the policies being enacted.
